Dear Mr. Derscheid:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 13, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
initial treatment plan for each resident within 30 calendar days
of admission.
One of six youth files reviewed did not have the initial treatment plan completed
within the required 30 days.
Repeat Violation Established 2021 Interim, CAP approved 8/25/2021.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
Two of four new hires did not have the required references obtained prior to
employment.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or
other country where the person usually resides or has resided in
the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other
country law enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
4

One of four new employees did not have a criminal background check completed
prior to hire.
Repeat Violation Established 2021 Interim, CAP approved 8/25/2021.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
One of four new employees did not have central registry documentation completed
prior to hire.
Repeat Violation Established 2021 Interim, CAP approved 8/25/2021.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
updated treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-
calendar days following the initial treatment plan.
One of six youth files reviewed did not have the updated treatment plan completed in
the required timeframe.
Repeat Violation Established 2021 Interim, CAP approved 8/25/2021.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
5

(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
Two of four closed youth files reviewed did not have all of the required information
completed in the discharge plan for the youth.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility did not require technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Discussed having all staff on the same training calendar by the calendar year
and not according to their hire date.
 Discussed the issues with obtaining dentals at this time due to lack of dentists
available. The facility was directed to document all efforts to complete the
exams in a timely manner and was given additional resource ideas for the
youth’s exams.
 Reviewed and discussed the current new employee hire checklist and
recommended they create a new document with language from the rules on
their checklist to eliminate any confusion on the rule expectations.
 Discussed the concern with lack of psychiatric availability for the youth and
ideas or resources to explore if the current concerns with their provider are not
resolved.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
2021 interim audit. The facility is in partial compliance with that corrective action plan
as they continued to have four repeat citations this period under review. The facility
6

had one special investigation during this period under review which did not result in
any citations and therefore did not require a corrective action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment reported a transitional year for Pineview Homes
with many key leadership positions which had led to some promotions from within as
well as external hires. The assessment discussed some of the staffing issues the
facility has had as well as issues with obtaining some of the medical and dental
appointments for youth due to lack of available providers and appointments in the
community. The assessment reviewed the current corrective action plans in place
from the previous audit and the improvement in some areas with those plans in place.
Interviews
The staff and youth at Pineview Homes were interviewed on May 13, 2022. The youth
all report their basic needs being met and all said they feel safe and respected at
Pineview Homes. None of the youth reported any concerns about the facility and two
of the youth reported it was the “best place” they had lived. The staff all report feeling
supported at Pineview Homes. The staff all felt that Pineview Homes is a safe place
for youth to reside and staff to work. The staff did not have any concerns about the
facility, and all reported they enjoyed working at the facility.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
